subject: RE: [junit] JUnit 4.1, running tests from and 1.6
msgSnippet: Yes, that s the default way of using jUnit. However, I am trying to something which needs for me to define the tests in one generic method. So, I would like to
messageBody:
Yes, that's the default way of using jUnit. However, I am trying to
something which needs for me to define the tests in one generic method.
So, I would like to turn off the fail fast behavior of jUnit.
Harsh.

-----Original Message-----
From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of
Andrew McDonagh
Sent: Thursday, June 15, 2006 2:46 PM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [junit] JUnit 4.1, running tests from and 1.6




public void testDescendingOrder() {
assertEquals( 9, Largest.largest( new int[] {9,8,7}));
}

public void testOutOfOrder() {
assertEquals( 44, Largest.largest( new int[] {8,9,7}));
}

public void testAscendingOrder() {
assertEquals( 32, Largest.largest( new int[] {7,8,9}));
}

Plus the benefits of this approach is that we can name the tests better
than simply 'testOrder' and the tests can run in and sequence.

Chaudhary, Harsh wrote:
>
> Hi,
> Is there a way in jUnit to override the failfast behavior e.g. my code
> looks like:
>
> public void testOrder() {
>
> assertEquals( 9, Largest.largest( new int[] {9,8,7}));
>
> assertEquals( 44, Largest.largest( new int[] {8,9,7}));
>
> assertEquals( 32, Largest.largest( new int[] {7,8,9}));
>
> }
>
> I know the 2nd and 3rd asserts would fail. I want to see both results
as
> having failed in my results. But jUnit just stops at the first
failure.
>
> Is there any way to change this behavior?
>
> Harsh.
>
